questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome , is a neurological condition caused by a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the PICA, a major artery that supplies the medulla. It results from damage to multiple structures in the medulla, including the nuclei of cranial nerves (such as the nucleus ambiguus), the spinothalamic tract, and the descending sympathetic pathways.
  • • Wallenberg syndrome or posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) syndrome
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery: The superior cerebellar artery primarily supplies the superior surface of the cerebellum. Blockage or injury to this artery can lead to symptoms related to dysfunction of the upper cerebellum but is not associated with the classic features of lateral medullary syndrome.
  • • Option A. Superior Cerebellar Artery:
  • • Option C . Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery : The posterior superior cerebellar artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and the superior cerebellar peduncle. It is not directly associated with the lateral medullary syndrome. Blockage of this artery can lead to symptoms related to the superior cerebellum but not the specific features seen in lateral medullary syndrome.
  • • Option C
  • • Posterior Superior Cerebellar Artery
  • • Option D. Cerebral Artery: The term "cerebral artery" is a broad term that refers to arteries supplying the brain, including the anterior, middle, and posterior cerebral arteries. Blockage or issues with these arteries can cause various types of strokes or neurological symptoms, but they are not directly related to lateral medullary syndrome, which specifically involves the medulla and the PICA.
  • • Option D. Cerebral Artery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a major artery that supplies the lateral and posterior parts of the medulla, as well as the inferior surface of the cerebellum. When there is an issue with the PICA, such as a clot or blockage, it can affect the blood supply to the lateral medulla. This leads to the classic symptoms of lateral medullary syndrome, including dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), hoarseness, vertigo, nystagmus (involuntary eye movements), ataxia (loss of coordination), and various sensory disturbances.
  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, typically results from a blockage or disruption of blood flow in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

questions.text: Insulin independent absorption occurs in all except: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adipose

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose uptake in adipose tissue is insulin-dependent, while RBCs, pancreas, and brain utilize insulin-independent mechanisms for glucose absorption.

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia
  • ➤ Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia
  • ➤ ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).
  • ➤ So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia). Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing: Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition) The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals . It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase
  • ➤ So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • ➤ Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing: Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • ➤ Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • ➤ Hepatosplenomegaly
  • ➤ Enlarged lymph nodes
  • ➤ Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • ➤ The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals . It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase
  • ➤ calcification of adrenals

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with a history of recurrent sinusitis presents with decreased vision, eye protrusion, and fever. A computed tomography (CT) scan was done. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital cellulitis with sinusitis is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention to prevent complications such as vision loss, intracranial spread of infection, and other severe outcomes.

questions.text: In Which of the following pathways, cyclooxygenase is involved? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prostaglandin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclooxygenase is involved in the prostaglandin synthesis pathway, converting arachidonic acid into prostaglandins, which are key mediators of inflammation, pain, and other physiological responses.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bag & Mask ventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The critical point in managing a neonate with a scaphoid abdomen, particularly when a condition like CDH is suspected, involves avoiding exacerbation of the hernia through inappropriate respiratory support techniques. Opting for intubation and controlled mechanical ventilation instead of bag & mask ventilation is crucial to prevent further complications and stabilize the infant's condition. Properly securing the airway and ensuring adequate ventilation without increasing the risk of further pulmonary or gastrointestinal injury is essential in the initial management of these patients.

questions.text: A male baby, born to a non-consanguineous couple, presents with blisters on areas of friction. Their previous baby also experienced similar issues and unfortunately passed away at the age of 2 weeks. What is the probable diagnosis?( INICET Nov 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epidermolysis bullosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The likely diagnosis in a neonate presenting with blistering at areas of friction , especially with a similar family history and early demise in a sibling , is Epidermolysis bullosa, a genetic condition causing extremely fragile skin leading to blister formation with minimal trauma.
  • ➤ neonate
  • ➤ blistering
  • ➤ friction
  • ➤ family history
  • ➤ early demise in a sibling
  • ➤ extremely fragile skin
  • ➤ minimal trauma.
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16
  • ➤ Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 71 Page no 71.4-71.16

questions.text: A patient had fever and sore throat for which he was started on antibiotic treatment. He develops abdominal pain. He has eosinophiluria and also has WBC casts in his urine. What is the likely diagnosis of the patient? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tubulointerstitial nephritis can present with eosinophiluria and WBC casts in the urine, often following antibiotic treatment, particularly with beta-lactam antibiotics. This condition results from an allergic reaction causing inflammation in the renal interstitium.

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bullet

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: Protein of HPV that inactivates Retinoblastoma?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The protein of HPV that inactivates the retinoblastoma protein is E7, forming a complex with Rb.
  • ➤ High-risk human papilloma virus (HPV) encodes two oncoproteins, E6 and E7, which are vital to viral replication and contribute to the development of cervical cancer. HPV16 E7 can target over 20 cellular proteins, but is best known for inactivating the retinoblastoma (RB) tumor suppressor.
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448132/
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448132/

questions.text: 3-point bony relationship is maintained in which fracture? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Supracondylar humerus fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.
  • ➤ The three-point bony relationship of the elbow is maintained only in the supracondylar humerus fracture because this fracture occurs above the bony landmarks associated with the relation.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave

options.label: C
options.text: Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision

options.label: D
options.text: Night blindness is a late feature

questions.correct_answer: D. Night blindness is a late feature
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: Identify the correct 'organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant' pair: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Candida Krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are true? (INICET NOV 2021) Due to increasing mammography, there occurs over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates. Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy. Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality. Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test. Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.
  • ➤ Screening for common cancers using relatively non-invasive tests is expected to lead to early diagnosis, allow more conservative surgical therapies with decreased morbidity, and potentially improve surgical cure rates and overall survival rates.
  • ➤ Current American Cancer Society guidelines advocate colon cancer screening for the average-risk population beginning at age 50 years. Recommended procedures include yearly fecal occult blood testing (FOBT)/fecal immunohistochemical testing (FIT), flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years, or FOBT/FIT and flexible sigmoidoscopy.
  • ➤ Visual inspection of the oral cavity has been widely used for screening oral cancer. The target population for oral cancer screening includes those aged 30 years and older who use tobacco and/or alcohol. Advantages of visual inspection include its feasibility, safety, acceptability, accuracy to detect oral precancerous and cancerous lesions, and efficacy and cost-effectiveness in reducing oral cancer mortality.
  • ➤ Pap smear is a screening test for cervical cancer. Screening should begin at age 21 years. For women aged between 21-29 years, screening should be done every 3 years with Pap smear examination. For women aged between 30-65 years, screening should be done every 5 years with both HPV and the Pap co-test.
  • ➤ Using mammography as a routine screening tool in women has been reported to reduce mortality from breast cancer. The United Kingdom recently established an independent expert panel to estimate the benefits and harms associated with screening women in its national screening program. The panel estimated that breast screening resulted in a 20% reduction in breast cancer mortality. The panel also noted over-diagnosis of breast carcinoma but concluded that breast screening confers significant benefits and should be continued.

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: All of the following Decreases GFR except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased Bowman Oncotic Pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When Bowman's capsule oncotic pressure increases, it pulls more water molecules from the glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space . This increases filtration, resulting in increased GFR. Proteins in Bowman's capsule would pull more water molecules towards them, which constitutes the filtration process.
  • ➤ glomerular capillaries into the Bowman's space
  • ➤ increased GFR.
  • ➤ pull more water molecules

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a part of AMTSL? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Early cord clamping

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct components of AMTSL include administering a uterotonic, controlled cord traction, and uterine massage. Early cord clamping is not part of AMTSL; instead, delayed cord clamping is recommended.

questions.text: Which JAK inhibitor drug is recommended for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in a patient who is not responding well to TNF-alpha blockers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tofacitinib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tofacitinib is the JAK inhibitor approved for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis in patients who have failed TNF-alpha blockers. Other JAK inhibitors used in rheumatological diseases include baricitinib and upadacitinib.

questions.text: Imagine being part of a team aiming to identify the link between a novel nutritional supplement and its potential effects on muscle growth. You're tasked with deciding the most appropriate study design to establish a cause-and-effect relationship. Among the given options, which study design would be the most effective for demonstrating a connection between cause and effect? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cohort study

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.
  • ➤ Cohort studies are ideal for establishing cause-and-effect relationships by following exposures over time and observing outcomes.

questions.text: Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023) 1.Pulmonary area 2.Erb’s area 3.Mitral area
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.
  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false about IL-12 except? (INICET NOV 2022) Increases production of interferon- γ Inhibits T cells Inhibits B cells Produced by macrophages
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Interleukin-12 (IL-12) is produced by macrophages and increases the production of interferon- γ (IFN- γ).

questions.text: A child presents with cyanosis. His chest radiograph is shown below. What is the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing a boot-shaped heart are suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
  • • TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease comprised of four components:
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure Overriding of aorta Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia
  • • Right ventricular hypertrophy –Boot shaped heart
  • • Ventricular septal defect – no heart failure
  • • Overriding of aorta
  • • Pulmonary stenosis (infundibulum)-Oligemia
  • • If ASD plus – pentalogy of Fallot
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ebstein's anomaly: Typically presents with an enlarged and downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle, which is not specifically indicated by the features in this X-ray.
  • • Option A. Ebstein's anomaly:
  • • Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA): Generally shows a characteristic "egg on a string" sign on chest X-ray, which is not evident in this image.
  • • Option B. Transposition of great arteries (TGA):
  • • Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC): Would show features like a "snowman" or "figure of 8" heart due to dilatation of the supra-cardiac veins, which is not visible here.
  • • Option D. Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tetralogy of Fallot is characterized by a distinctive boot-shaped heart on chest X-ray, correlating with the anatomical components of this congenital heart defect, making it a key diagnostic feature in cyanotic pediatric patients .
  • ➤ .

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with 15 days of fever and altered sensorium for 1 day. A rapid diagnostic test was done, and Plasmodium falciparum was diagnosed. Which of the following is not a complication? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arterial pH >7.2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnostic criteria for identifying complicated falciparum malaria, based on clinical and laboratory findings:
  • ➤ Arterial pH : An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria. Bicarbonate Levels : A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria. Base Deficit : A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease. Hemoglobin : A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity. Venous Lactate : A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection. Blood Glucose : A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria. Creatinine Levels : A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria. Urine Output : A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Arterial pH : An arterial pH of less than 7.25 is indicative of complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Arterial pH
  • ➤ Bicarbonate Levels : A bicarbonate level of less than 15 is also a sign of complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Bicarbonate Levels
  • ➤ Base Deficit : A base deficit of more than 8 is another indicator of severe disease.
  • ➤ Base Deficit
  • ➤ Hemoglobin : A hemoglobin level of less than 5, or the presence of hemoglobinuria, are significant markers of severity.
  • ➤ Hemoglobin
  • ➤ Venous Lactate : A venous lactate level of more than 5 further confirms the complexity and severity of the malaria infection.
  • ➤ Venous Lactate
  • ➤ Blood Glucose : A blood glucose level less than 40 mg/dL is a critical indicator of complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Blood Glucose
  • ➤ Creatinine Levels : A creatinine level exceeding 3 mg/dL points to significant renal impairment associated with severe malaria.
  • ➤ Creatinine Levels
  • ➤ Urine Output : A urine output of less than 400 mL per day, despite adequate rehydration with IV fluids, also signifies complicated falciparum malaria.
  • ➤ Urine Output

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with abdominal pain and distension. She has a history of chronic constipation. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith

options.label: D
options.text: Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sigmoid volvulus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The abdominal X-ray shows a characteristic "coffee bean sign," which is indicative of a sigmoid volvulus. This radiological sign represents a massively distended sigmoid colon twisted on itself, resembling a bent tube or coffee bean. This condition is more common in elderly individuals, particularly those with a history of chronic constipation, due to the increased bowel length and mobility, combined with decreased bowel tone. Sigmoid volvulus can lead to severe abdominal pain and distension, as observed in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith: Typically presents with signs of obstruction but lacks the specific 'coffee bean' appearance associated with volvulus.
  • • Option B. Large bowel obstruction due to fecolith:
  • • Option C. Cecal volvulus: Would show a single dilated loop of bowel, often with haustrations, and generally appears in a different location and shape compared to the sigmoid volvulus.
  • • Option C. Cecal volvulus:
  • • Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation: Would likely show signs of free air under the diaphragm on an X-ray, which is not visible in the provided image.
  • • Option D. Small bowel obstruction due to bowel perforation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.
  • • The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: Identify the factor 'L' which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in given coagulation cascade? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Factor VII

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Factor VII is the key clotting factor that combines with tissue factor to activate Factor IX and Factor X, playing a crucial role in the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade.

questions.text: How is cerebral perfusion pressure calculated? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.correct_answer: D. Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Mean arterial pressure - intracranial pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is calculated by subtracting the intracranial pressure (ICP) from the mean arterial pressure (MAP). This measurement is crucial for ensuring adequate blood flow and oxygen delivery to the brain.

questions.text: Concerning the mechanism of action of various antimicrobial drugs, which of the following statements is FALSE? (INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.correct_answer: A. Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Linezolid: Binds to 30S ribosome and inhibits protein synthesis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Linezolid binds to the 50S subunit of bacterial ribosomes, not the 30S subunit, making the statement that it binds to the 30S subunit and inhibits protein synthesis false. The other drugs mentioned have their mechanisms correctly stated.

questions.text: Regarding Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) in children, which of the following statements is false? (INICET NOV 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

options.label: B
options.text: IV immunoglobulins are the first line of treatment

options.label: C
options.text: Areflexia in the weaker arm is included in diagnostic criteria

questions.correct_answer: A. Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmapheresis is not effective in refractory GBS

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmapheresis and IVIG are effective treatment options for GBS, including refractory cases, with neither being superior to the other. Never use immunosuppression or steroids in acute GBS.
  • ➤ Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS
  • ➤ Level of diagnostic certainty in Brighton criteria for GBS

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On examination of the oral cavity, a white pseudomembrane was visualized. A swab was taken from it and stained as given in the image below. What is the procedure for the following staining? (INICET NOV 2021) Albert's stain- I Acid alcohol Gram's iodine Safranin Methylene blue Crystal violet Carbol fuschin Acetone
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 6, 3, 8, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct Gram staining procedure for identifying Corynebacterium diphtheriae includes the steps of applying crystal violet, adding Gram's iodine, decolorizing with acetone, and counterstaining with safranin.

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:
  • • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain. Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.
  • • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • • Contractions:
  • • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.
  • • Cervical Changes:
  • • The incorrect statement is Option D . A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.
  • • Option D
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.
  • • Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix:
  • • Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.
  • • Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm:
  • • Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.
  • • Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: Eonism can be defined as? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. Wearing clothes of opposite sex
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Eonism or transvestism is the act of wearing clothes of the opposite sex for pleasure, named after Charles Eon de Beaumont.

questions.text: Fingerprint develops in how many weeks of intrauterine life? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 12-16

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fingerprints start developing between 12-16 weeks of intrauterine life and are completed by 24 weeks, providing a unique identification for the individual that remains unchanged throughout their life.

questions.text: A female patient presents to the hospital with palpitations. Her vitals are stable, and the ECG shows the following. Which of the following is used as first-line management to treat the condition? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For stable, regular narrow complex tachycardia, adenosine is the first-line pharmacological treatment.

questions.text: Histological examination of a cervical lymph node biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tuberculosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of caseous necrosis and a ring of lymphocytes in the histological examination of cervical lymph nodes strongly suggests tuberculosis as the diagnosis.

questions.text: All of the following cause a right shift of the oxygen- hemoglobin dissociation curve, except? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Increased HbF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right with factors that decrease the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, such as increased 2,3 BPG, acidosis, and increased CO₂. In contrast, increased fetal hemoglobin (HbF) causes a left shift, indicating higher oxygen affinity.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 24 hr urinary total metanephrines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 24-hour urinary metanephrines test with fractionated catecholamines is the initial recommended test for diagnosing pheochromocytoma in the general population. Plasma metanephrines can be considered in high-risk populations (such as those with a family history or genetic syndromes).

questions.text: Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020) 1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement 2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease 3. Resolves with desferrioxamine 4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement 5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.
  • ➤ Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: In the accompanying illustration, a treatment approach for a patient with lymphatic filariasis is depicted. Which type of preventive method is illustrated in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Disability limitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.
  • ➤ Disability limitation is a mode of tertiary prevention aimed at managing existing disease and preventing further complications, as illustrated in the treatment approach for a patient with chronic lymphatic filariasis in the image.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)

options.label: D
options.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: Match the diseases with their maximum incubation period. ( INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-c, 3-a, 4-b

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HbsAg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.
  • ➤ The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever and nuchal rigidity. The resident was instructed to perform a lumbar puncture on this patient. What is the correct order of managing this patient? ( INICET MAY 2022) Place IV cannula and give fluids at 40 mL/h Start injection ceftriaxone Send CSF sample for biochemistry and microanalysis Perform guarded lumbar puncture
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 4, 3, 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In suspected meningitis, the ideal sequence is to secure samples for microbiological diagnosis before starting antibiotics, when clinically feasible. However, if there will be a significant delay in performing the lumbar puncture or if the patient is critically ill, antibiotics should not be delayed. The sequence emphasizes balancing the need for accurate diagnosis with timely intervention.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy, a known case of type I DM, undergoes the following test for the detection of KB. Which is this test: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rothera's Test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rothera's Test is a commonly used laboratory test to detect the presence of ketone bodies, specifically acetoacetate, in urine or blood samples. It is particularly relevant in the context of diabetes mellitus, as individuals with uncontrolled diabetes, especially type I diabetes, may experience an increase in ketone production.
  • ➤ In type I diabetes, the body is unable to produce sufficient insulin, resulting in a lack of glucose utilization by cells for energy. As a result, the body begins to break down fats as an alternative energy source, leading to the production of ketone bodies, including acetoacetate.
